Quick cribsheets for handling python environments through different tools

## [Pip](https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/)
```bash
python3 -m venv .env                        # Create venv off whatever python version you call from in folder .env
source .env/bin/activate
python -m pip install --update pip          # Bring pip up-to-date first
pip install -r requirements.txt             # install modules listed in requirements.txt
```

[Pip documentation - requirements file format](https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/requirements-file-format/)

## [Conda](https://docs.conda.io/en/latest/)

Creating it first time:

```bash
conda create --name environment_name
conda activate environment_name
conda install numpy pandas pdfplumber ipykernel jupyter openpyxl  # installing like this out of laziness
conda env export > environment.yml                                # writing an environment file so I can properly restore it

```

To build the environment using the stored `environment.yml`:

```bash
conda env create -f environment.yml                     # recreate the environment described in that environment
conda activate environment_name                         # activate
```


## Bonus:  [renv (R)](https://rstudio.github.io/renv/)

```bash
install.packages("renv")           # Install environment manager
renv::init()                       # First run, create environment for project (current dir)
renv::activate()                   # Or activate after navigating to project
install.packages("readr")          # Install packages
renv::snapshot()                   # Store exact package configuration to renv.lock file
renv::restore()                    # Recreate environment from renv.lock file
renv::revert()                     # Revert environment to that specified in renv.lock file
```
